title: Tension Pneumothorax Management
stem: You are caring for Mr. Johnson, a 62-year-old male admitted following a motor vehicle accident. The patient has a chest tube connected to a three-chamber drainage system. Based on the EHR data, evaluate the patient's condition and determine the appropriate nursing interventions.

itemContext.SBAR:
14:00 Report:
Situation: Mr. Johnson, 62-year-old male, post-MVA, intubated and on mechanical ventilation. He is restless and agitated.
Background: Admitted 2 hours ago with multiple rib fractures and a right hemopneumothorax. A 28 French chest tube was inserted in the ED. Initial output was 300 mL of blood. Patient has a history of COPD managed with inhalers.
Assessment: HR 140 bpm, BP 90/50 mmHg, RR 32 and labored, SpO2 88% despite 100% FiO2. Trachea deviated to the left. No breath sounds on the right side. Chest tube output has decreased to 10 mL in the last hour. Subcutaneous emphysema is palpable around the chest tube insertion site. ABG: pH 7.20, PaCO2 60, PaO2 55, HCO3 24.
Recommendation: Suspect tension pneumothorax. Stat chest X-ray and consider needle thoracostomy.
itemContext.Labs: ABG: pH 7.20, PaCO2 60 mmHg, PaO2 55 mmHg, HCO3 24 mEq/L
itemContext.Vitals: HR 140 bpm, BP 90/50 mmHg, RR 32 and labored, SpO2 88% (FiO2 100%)
itemContext.MAR: No medications currently infusing. Orders for PRN pain medication (morphine) and sedation (propofol) are available.

responseOptions.rationale: Needle thoracostomy is the immediate intervention for a tension pneumothorax to relieve the pressure and allow for lung re-expansion. The patient's clinical presentation (tracheal deviation, absent breath sounds, hypoxia, hypotension) strongly suggests a tension pneumothorax, making immediate intervention crucial. This buys time for definitive treatment with a chest tube.

responseOptions.text: Administer a bolus of IV fluids.
responseOptions.rationale: Hypotension is a common consequence of tension pneumothorax due to decreased venous return from intrathoracic pressure. Administering IV fluids can help to improve blood pressure and stabilize the patient hemodynamically. This intervention addresses the decreased preload caused by the pneumothorax.

While hypoxia is present, increasing the FiO2 alone will not address the underlying problem of lung compression. The pneumothorax impairs oxygenation and ventilation, so relieving the pressure is the priority. Increasing FiO2 alone will not resolve the tension pneumothorax.

responseOptions.text: Reposition the patient to a high-Fowler's position.
responseOptions.rationale: Repositioning the patient will not address the underlying pneumothorax. A high-Fowler's position may improve ventilation in some respiratory conditions, but it will not relieve the pressure causing the tension pneumothorax. Immediate interventions are needed to relieve intrathoracic pressure.

responseOptions.text: Assess the chest tube for kinks or occlusions.
responseOptions.rationale: While assessment of the chest tube is important, it is not the priority. The rapid deterioration of the patient suggests a developing or worsening tension pneumothorax that requires immediate intervention. Addressing the tension pneumothorax is more urgent than troubleshooting the existing chest tube.

responseOptions.text: Prepare to administer PRN morphine for pain.
responseOptions.rationale: While pain management is important, it is not the priority in this situation. The patient is likely experiencing pain due to the rib fractures, but addressing the life-threatening tension pneumothorax takes precedence. Administering morphine may also worsen respiratory depression.

responseOptions.text: Notify the healthcare provider of the patient's condition.
responseOptions.rationale: Notifying the healthcare provider is an essential step in escalating care for a deteriorating patient. While immediate actions are taken, keeping the provider informed ensures coordinated care and potential further interventions. This ensures the provider is aware and can provide further orders or interventions.

clinicalPearls: Tension pneumothorax is a life-threatening condition requiring immediate intervention. Key signs include tracheal deviation, absent breath sounds on the affected side, hypotension, and hypoxia despite oxygen administration. Rapid recognition and treatment are crucial to prevent cardiovascular collapse.
questionTrap: Many students will focus on the chest tube drainage, which is a distractor. The key is recognizing the signs and symptoms of a tension pneumothorax and understanding the need for immediate intervention to relieve the pressure.
mnemonic: Tension Pneumothorax: Tracheal deviation, Absent breath sounds, Needle thoracostomy needed!
